description.plain:
Guns N' Roses was the most dangerous band in the world in the late 80s and early 90s. Led by singer Axl Rose and stylish guitarist Slash, they mixed the passion of blues, the heaviness of rock, and the attitude of punk, bringing forth a breath of fresh air to a music scene dominated by cheesy hair metal bands.

Their debut album, Appetite for Destruction, is the best selling debut of all-time. They outsold a headlining Aerosmith on their first major tour, released two double albums (Use Your Illusion I & II) simultaneously, and soon would play to audiences in excesses of 20,000 people.

However, cracks started forming in the band, as classic era drummer Steven Adler was fired from the band before the “Use Your Illusion” releases and founding rhythm guitarist Izzy Stradlin left abruptly during the ensuing tour. They were replaced by Matt Sorum and Gilby Clarke, respectively, with keyboardist Dizzy Reed joining the band and expanding the group’s sound.

After releasing a punk-rock covers album (“The Spaghetti Incident?”) in 1993, progress on a follow-up album stalled due to creative differences between Rose and Slash. Tensions arose and personal conflicts caused the band to begin to fall apart. By 1998, only Rose and Reed remained in the band from the “Illusion”-era.

Several different lineups worked on the new album for over a decade; with musicians as diverse as punk bassist Tommy Stinson, virtuoso guitarist Buckethead, and several former touring members of Nine Inch Nails. The result, 2008’s Chinese Democracy, was met with positive reviews but undersold expectations.

Rose toured heavily from 2001 until 2014 with various musicians from the “Chinese” era, before Slash and bassist Duff McKagan rejoined the band in 2016, marking the first time those three played together since 1994. The current lineup includes Rose, Slash, McKagan, Reed, “Chinese Democracy”-era rhythm guitarist Richard Fortus and drummer Frank Ferrer, and new keyboardist Melissa Reese.

The group’s “Not In this Lifetime…” quasi-reunion tour became a massive success, grossing over $560 million by 2019, the third highest-grossing tour of all time.

songs.full_title: Sweet Child O’ Mine by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Sweet Child O’ Mine

description.plain:
“Sweet Child O’ Mine” is the 9th track of Guns N’ Roses’ debut album Appetite for Destruction. The song became GNR’s most successful single, topping the Billboard Hot 100.

The guitar solo was ranked as the 37th greatest solo of all-time by Guitar World. Amazingly, it was recorded in one take.

The lyrics were written by frontman Axl Rose as a dedication to his then-girlfriend Erin Everly. Once he heard guitarist Slash noodling downstairs, Axl found the musical backing he needed.

In 2015, the Australian website MAX TV revealed the song’s striking similarity to “Unpublished Critics,” a song released in 1981 by the band Australian Crawl. Duff McKagan, bass player for Guns N' Roses during the recording of “Sweet Child O' Mine,” said the similarities were startling. Speaking to Radio.com in 2015:

It is pretty stunning. But we didn’t steal it from them! I swear [puts his hand on his heart], I never heard that song until a couple of days ago."

songs.full_title: November Rain by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: November Rain

description.plain:
This piano ballad grand masterpiece became the signature song and the centerpiece of their simultaneous twin double album releases Use Your Illusion I and Use Your Illusion II.

Clocking in at almost 9 minutes, “November Rain” features Rose’s desperate vocal and heartfelt piano. A depressing autumn tale of lost love, Slash’s inspired soaring guitar solos and the band’s dramatic dynamics over a crescendo of a swirling string section backed by a powerful choir make the song an instant classic.

The song had been a work-in-progress since 1983. Former GNR co-founder and guitarist Tracii Guns explained:

When we were doing that EP for L.A. Guns, like ‘83? He was playing “November Rain”—and it was called “November Rain”—you know, on piano. Way back then, it was the only thing he knew how to play, but it was his. He’d go, “Someday this song is gonna be really cool.” And I’d go, “It’s cool now.” “But it’s not done”, you know, he used to say. And, like, anytime we’d be at a hotel or anywhere, there’d be a piano; he’d just kinda play that music. And I’d go, “When are you gonna finish that already”, you know? And he’d go, “I don’t know what to do with it.”

The lyrics and video are based on a short story by Del James called “Without You” from a collection called The Language of Fear, which was brought back to market in 2008 after being out of print. The new version of the book contains an intro by Axl Rose, who wrote:

Del James has a personal knowledge of most of the situations he writes about, and has a love of the gutter from having been there.

James has also contributed lyrics to GNR songs The Garden" and “Yesterdays” and has directed several music videos.

“November Rain” hit #3 on the U.S. Billboard Hot 100, #9 in Germany where it charted for 51 weeks, #5 in Australia riding the Top 10 for 22 weeks and #7 in New Zealand ending 1992 as their second best-selling single.

songs.full_title: Welcome to the Jungle by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Welcome to the Jungle

description.plain:
Guns N' Roses introduces itself with a hard-hitting ode to a wild place that can tear anyone apart. No wonder it’s their usual setlist opener (except in the Chinese Democracy tour, where the eponymous song did the honors) and a mainstay of many sports events.

According to an interview published by Hit Parader in March 1988:

Axl wrote the words while visiting his long-time friend Tori in Kingston, Washington, a town outside of Seattle. It’s a big city, but at the same time, it’s still a small city compared to Los Angeles and the things that you’re gonna learn. It seemed a lot more rural up there. Axl just wrote how it looked to him. If someone comes to town and they want to find something, they can find whatever they want.

There has been said that Axl and a friend heard the exact same phrase that is used in the song from the lips of a homeless man, as soon as they climbed down from a bus, just after arriving in New York:

You know where you are?
You’re in the jungle, babe
You’re gonna die!

Oh my God
Jump

If you want it you're going to bleed, but it's the price you pay

In the jungle, welcome to the jungle
Feel my, my, my, my serpentine
Oh, ah, I wanna hear you scream

Moaning

Welcome to the jungle, it gets worse here everyday
You learn to live like an animal in the jungle where we play
If you got a hunger for what you see, you'll take it eventually
You can have anything you want, but you better not take it from me

In the jungle, welcome to the jungle
Watch it bring you to your shun-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n, knees, knees
Mwah, I wanna watch you bleed

And when you're high, you never
Ever want to come down
So down, so down, so down, yeah


You know where you are?

songs.full_title: Don’t Cry by Guns N' Roses (Ft. Shannon Hoon)
songs.title: Don’t Cry

description.plain:
“Don’t Cry” is a Guns N' Roses melodic ballad off their 1991 album Use Your Illusion I.

It was one of the first compositions written by Axl Rose and Izzy Stradlin while in Los Angeles, being present in the band’s demo tape to Geffen in 1986. Axl once described the song as being about “A woman leaving a man.” The girl is someone who Izzy Stradlin once dated, and who Axl was attracted to. Axl really liked this girl, but things couldn’t work out between them, which really hurt him and inspired him to write the song.

The music video started a trilogy, and translates how Axl’s life was going awry:

With our video for “Don’t Cry,” and the fight that Stephanie Seymour, (his then-girlfriend) and I had over the gun, you don’t necessarily know what’s going on. But in real life that happened with Erin Everly (his ex-wife) and myself. I was going to shoot myself. We fought over the gun and I finally let her win.

According to Matt Sorum, “November Rain,” “Don’t Cry” and “Estranged” were conceived as one song, and the three tracks form a trilogy of sorts. Sorum played the same drum fill throughout those three songs and took some criticism for doing so—notably from former Dream Theater drummer Mike Portnoy.

Sorum points out that this was intentional, a way of unifying the songs. “That was my part in tying enough songs together to make it one voice,” he told us.

songs.full_title: Knockin’ on Heaven’s Door by Guns N' Roses (Ft. ​The Waters)
songs.title: Knockin’ on Heaven’s Door

description.plain:
This song was originally written and performed by Bob Dylan for the soundtrack to the 1973 film Pat Garrett & Billy the Kid. GNR’s version is featured in 1990’s Days of Thunder.

The song is about an officer who accidentally shot a kid and is dying, maybe from suicide, and hoping he gets let into heaven, hence “Knockin’ on heaven’s door.” He knocks because he thinks he needs permission to enter here instead of Hell.

songs.full_title: Civil War by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Civil War

description.plain:
Before its release as the opening track on the Guns N' Roses album Use Your Illusion II in 1991, “Civil War” first appeared on the 1990 charity compilation Nobody’s Child: Romanian Angel Appeal. It was also released as an EP in 1993 and included on the band’s Greatest Hits album in 2004.

In his autobiography, Slash stated that the song was initially an instrumental he created before the Japanese leg of the Appetite for Destruction tour. Later, Rose would write the lyrics and shape it into a full song. Because it was recorded in 1990, it is the only song on the Use Your Illusion albums to feature Steven Adler playing drums, due to his playing being negatively affected by his heroin habit—the final cut is a mix of 20–30 takes, mixed to allow the rest of the band to be able to follow it properly. First played live at Farm Aid in 1990, this also marked original drummer Adler’s first and last time performing the song.

Created as an anti-war protest song, it features lead vocalist Axl Rose whistling the song “When Johnny Comes Marching Home,” which was written during the American Civil War. Other featured samples are speeches from a Peruvian Shining Path guerrilla general and the 1967 movie, Cool Hand Luke.

Duff McKagan explained the origins of “Civil War” during an interview on Rockline:

Basically it was a riff that we would do at sound-checks. Axl came up with a couple of lines at the beginning. And… I went to a peace march, when I was a little kid, with my mom. I was like four years old. For Martin Luther King. And that’s when: “Did you wear the black arm band when they shot the man who said: ‘Peace could last forever’?” It’s just true-life experiences, really.

However, that line is not actually a direct quote of MLK; it’s more of what Duff took away from his message.

songs.full_title: Patience by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Patience

description.plain:
One of the Guns N' Roses' most famous and beautiful songs. This song was the main single of their second album G N' R Lies.

Played with only three guitars, it remains one of rock’s best acoustic songs of all time. Still, the last part is played with electric guitars live.

The song is about a man missing his ex, and tells her that the problems they had will work themselves out fine with patience and things will be alright again.

songs.full_title: Paradise City by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Paradise City

description.plain:
A Guns N' Roses masterpiece, usually the last song in every setlist, “Paradise City” was the sixth track for debut studio album Appetite for Destruction, and upon its single release in November 1988, reached #5 in the US and #6 in the UK. The lyrics follow a man frustrated with the big city life, combining a singalong “take me back home!” chorus with “this town is tearing me apart” verses. It’s also the only track in Appetite for Destruction featuring a synth.

The song appears as the theme song for the EA video game Burnout: Paradise, which is set in the fictional “Paradise City.”

songs.full_title: One in a Million by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: One in a Million

description.plain:
One of Guns n' Roses' most controversial songs.

Axl Rose moved to the big city of Los Angeles from a small town in Indiana, and having had some negative experiences with the groups he wrote about in this song, those events colored his perception when penning the lyrics.

Whether from harassment by police, seeing people being ripped off by black hustlers selling fake goods at the Greyhound station, being treated as an outsider by immigrant store owners within the USA, or an attempted rape by a gay man when hitchhiking, these experiences gave birth to the song.  Fed up with it all, he sings about trying to get away from it.

Axl explains much of this during interviews in Rolling Stone Magazine in August, 1989 and April, 1992.

songs.full_title: Rocket Queen by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Rocket Queen

description.plain:
The song was named after Barbi Von Grief, a girl Axl was infatuated during GNR’s club days. As stated in Slash’s autobiography, Barbi “Rocket Queen” Von Greif was only 18-years old when she was the head of the underground hard rock scene in LA, she was notorious for being a partier.



The song is infamous for containing audio of a woman orgasming during the guitar solo. These noises were provided by Adriana Smith, Steven Adler’s girlfriend at the time, by having sex with Axl in the recording studio.

songs.full_title: Nightrain by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Nightrain

description.plain: “Nightrain” is one of the ‘feel good songs’ by Guns N' Roses, an ode to getting wasted with Night Train wine. As described by Slash at their infamous show at the Ritz in 1988, the song is about “a walk in the park.” In reality (and as revealed in said guitarist’s autobiography), the idea for “Nightrain” came during a walk down an avenue after getting drunk, singing the future chorus, “I’m on the night train!”.

songs.full_title: Estranged by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Estranged

description.plain:
The third song in the unofficial “Del James trilogy” including “Don’t Cry” and “November Rain.”

The director of the music video, Andy Morahan, said:

By the time we got to ‘Estranged’, Axl had split up with Stephanie Seymour, and he said, ‘I never want a girl in a video again. I’d rather go out with a dolphin.’ Which is why I put dolphins all over the video.

According to Matt Sorum, “November Rain,” “Don’t Cry” and “Estranged” form a trilogy of sorts. Sorum played the same drum fill throughout those three songs, and took some criticism for doing so – notably from former Dream Theater drummer Mike Portnoy.

Sorum points out that this was intentional, a way of unifying the songs. “That was my part in tying enough songs together to make it one voice,” he told us.

songs.full_title: Mr. Brownstone by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Mr. Brownstone

description.plain:
“Mr. Brownstone” was only released as a promotional single in the UK ahead of the release of Appetite for Destruction in 1987. It was featured as the B-Side of both “Welcome to the Jungle” and “It’s So Easy.” As a staple of live Guns N' Roses shows, the song was the first to be written after signing to Geffen Records.

In his autobiography, Slash explained that the lyrics depict a typical day in the life of Guns N' Roses. Both the lyrics and music were improvised by Slash and Izzy Stradlin while complaining about being addicts—“brownstone” is a slang term for heroin. Throughout the song, explicit references are made about building a tolerance to the drug.

songs.full_title: You Could Be Mine by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: You Could Be Mine

description.plain:
“You Could Be Mine” is one of Guns N' Roses' greatest hits. Many remember it for being the theme song of Terminator II: Judgment Day. Axl Rose and Izzy Stradlin co-wrote this song, and it’s mocking a potential suitor expressing how she’s too screwed up to be his.

The movie’s symbolism when the Terminator carries a box of roses with a gun inside it pays tribute to the band’s name.

Music Video http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FFnZOv8jdWQ

songs.full_title: My Michelle by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: My Michelle

description.plain: Axl Rose writes an ode to his friend Michelle Young, inspired by her wanting a song about her. Only Axl failed to make a “Michelle ma belle” straightforward ballad  and wound up describing what a  trainwreck of a life Michelle had (in her own words, “At the time, I didn’t care because I was so fucked up”). Young ended up loving the song because it was sincere. Though the attention it brought her led to some negative repercussions.

songs.full_title: This I Love by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: This I Love

description.plain:
A song that goes way back to 1993. In ‘93, Axl told Hit Parader:

I wrote and recorded a new love song that I want on the next record called “This I Love,” that’s the heaviest thing that I’ve ever done.

Rose reiterated in a 2008 interview that it was still the ‘heaviest’ thing he’s written. Rose mentioned the orchestral part on the bridge being his favorite part of the entire album.

Rose also used the song as an example in defense of Chinese Democracy being a “Guns N' Roses record” and not an “Axl Rose solo record,” saying he initially had no intention of recording the song before guitarist Robin Finck and producer Caram Costanzo convinced him to. Ironically it is the only song on the album with lyrics and instruments credited solely to Rose.

songs.full_title: Think About You by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Think About You

description.plain:
“Think About You” is the eighth track on Guns N' Roses' debut album Appetite for Destruction. It was mostly composed by Izzy Stradlin, then the rhythm guitarist, who even played the song’s solo.  Izzy summed up the track as “a quick love song about drugs, sex, Hollywood and money.”

 The song was played very frequently in GNR’s early days, but it was played less and less as time went on—only to see a revival in the early 2000s as Axl decided to finally put the long-dormant band on stage.

songs.full_title: Chinese Democracy by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Chinese Democracy

description.plain:
Chinese Democracy is the lead single of Guns N' Roses’s 2008 album Chinese Democracy. The song was written around 1999 primarily by Axl Rose and drummer Josh Freese (guitarists Paul Tobias and Robin Finck, bassist Tommy Stinson, keyboardist Dizzy Reed and producers Caram Costanzo & Eric Caudieux are also credited as songwriters)

Axl Rose had the following to say about the song:

The movie Kundun was on TV about the Dalai Lama. I was getting ready to leave… and it was the end of the movie. And the Dalai Lama is about to cross over the border, to you know, be in exile for the rest of his life from his own country. And he looks back at the men who helped him, and you know he’s escaped the Chinese government. And he looks back at them and he waves and they wave at him. And then they show a scene where he looks back at them again and he sees every one of them dead. Because he knew they would be killed, and they knew that in helping him they would be killed. And you know the emotion in this next song, that’s all that’s about. It’s not like an intelligent song. It doesn’t have the answer to anything. And it’s not necessarily pro or con about China. It’s just that right now China symbolizes one of the strongest, yet most oppressive countries and governments in the world. And we [Americans] are fortunate to live in a free country. And so in thinking about that it just kinda upset me, and we wrote this little song called “Chinese Democracy.”

The song had a working title of “Chinese Stew”.

songs.full_title: Coma by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Coma

description.plain:
Appearing on Use Your Illusion I, the longest Guns N' Roses song (so far) is the 10 minutes, 14 seconds long chorus-less “Coma”. Lyrically, the song is one of their heaviest, taking about the effects of self-destruction, being suspended deep in a coma and considering suicide.

Some say “Coma” reflects substance abuse as a means of escaping reality and Axl Rose’s struggle to understand himself. Rose has been known to have attended therapy to help him understand the root of his frustration and destructiveness.

In his autobiography, Slash states that he initially wrote the guitar parts while in a “heroin delirium” following the Appetite For Destruction tour. Axl had trouble fitting lyrics to it. In 1992, Axl Rose told Interview magazine:

I tried to write that song for a year, and couldn’t. I went to write it at the studio and passed out. I woke up two hours later and sat down and wrote the whole end of the song, like, just off the top of my head. It was like, don’t even know what’s coming out, man, but it’s coming. I think one of the best things that I’ve ever written was maybe the end segment of the song “Coma”. It just poured out.

When interviewed by Kurt Loder for MTV’s Famous Last Words, Axl described the situation behind the lyrics:

There’s a song called “Coma” that’s like 11 minutes 45 seconds long with no chorus. And I think there was only one verse that somewhere it repeats itself. It’s Slash’s baby. It’s his monster. The song used to be called Girth. But I started writing about when I OD'ed 4 years ago. The reason I OD’d was because of stress. I couldn’t take it. And I just grabbed the bottle of pills in an argument and just gulped them down and I ended up in the hospital. But I liked that I wasn’t in the fight anymore and I was fully conscious that I was leaving. I liked that. But then I go, all of a sudden, my first real thoughts were that “okay, you haven’t toured enough. The record’s not going to last; it’s going to be forgotten. This and that, you have work to do. Get out of this.” And I went “No!” and I woke up, you know, and pulled myself out of it. But in the describing of that, some people could take it wrong and think this means “go put yourself into a coma,” you know. And so it’s really tricky, and I’m still playing with the words to figure out how to, like, show some hope in there.

songs.full_title: Since I Don't Have You by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Since I Don’t Have You

description.plain:
Originally a 1958 doo-wop single by The Skyliners, “Since I Don’t Have You” is considered to be among some of the best heartbreak ballads ever recorded.

Guns N’ Roses later covered the song on The Spaghetti Incident?, from which it was taken as the album’s third single in 1994. Maintaining the original version’s slow, yearning tempo and clean-cut piano melody, the lyrics reflect on the termination of a relationship. Devastated by the loss of a great love, the narrator feels incomplete and lifeless. In this moment, they are eclipsed by emotion and have no plans or hope for the long-term.

The song became a top 10 hit in the UK, and remains the last music video officially released by the band to this date. The video is notable for featuring actor Gary Oldman as a demon taunting singer Axl Rose.

songs.full_title: ABSUЯD by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: ABSUЯD

description.plain:
Introduced as a new Guns N' Roses song by lead singer Axl Rose, “Absurd” is a reworked version of “Silkworms” from the Chinese Democracy sessions. It is the first new song performed by the band since the return of original members Slash and Duff McKagan.

The song was released as a single on August 6, 2021, the first newly recorded material released since November 2008.

songs.full_title: 14 Years by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: 14 Years

description.plain:
As one of the few Guns N’ Roses songs sung almost entirely by former rhythm guitarist Izzy Stradlin, “14 Years” was only performed live up until his departure in 1991. The song would later be returned to their set list in 2012 during the few concerts where Stradlin would make a guest appearance.

This song has been hypothesised to be about Stradlin’s friendship with Axl Rose, who he had known for 14 years by the time the song was believed to have been written. While one would assume this as a song to celebrate friendship, the lyrics reflect a deeper, more conflicted history. This theory however, has never been confirmed by the band, and those who oppose the theory discredit it based on the assumption that Axl would never let a song like this be released if it were about tension within the band, especially involving him. Instead, it is proposed that this song’s about a past relationship of Izzy’s.

songs.full_title: Out ta Get Me by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Out ta Get Me

description.plain:
“Out Ta Get Me” talks about how Axl Rose got harassed by the police for things that he didn’t do. So no matter what they do to him, they will never get him for something he didn’t do. As he said:

We wanna dedicate this song to the people that try to hold you back, the people that tell you how to live, people that tell you how to dress, people that tell you how to talk, people that tell you what you can say and what you can’t say. I personally don’t need that, I don’t need that shit in my life. Those are the kind of people that have been getting me down. They make me feel like somebody, somebody out there is out to get me!

songs.full_title: Get in the Ring by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Get in the Ring

description.plain:
Originally written by Duff McKagan as ‘Why Do You Look At Me When You Hate Me?’, the song is a message from Guns N Roses to the Rock N' Roll journalists of the early 90’s who according to Rose were spreading lies about the band for publicity and ripping off the fans with B.S. stories. Critics from Hit Parader (Andy Secher), Circus, Kerrang! (Mick Wall) and Spin (Bob Guccione, Jr.) are all mentioned by name. Get in the Ring" is notorious for its amount of swearing.

Allegedly, Mick Wall of Kerrang! music magazine was mentioned because of his book Guns N' Roses: The Most Dangerous Band in the World, which was a no holds barred collection of interviews and stories about the band. Wall denies this, and claims that the real reason for his mention was an interview he wrote in early 1990 for Kerrang! about Axl Rose’s threat to harm Vince Neil of Mötley Crüe over an incident involving Neil’s wife and Izzy Stradlin.

songs.full_title: Breakdown by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Breakdown

description.plain:
“Breakdown” is written by Axl Rose and is one of the most distinguishable songs off the album as it opens with a banjo. As Slash explained:

That’s a five-string banjo tuned to guitar because I don’t know anything about banjo. It’s something I wrote off-the-cuff when Axl came up with that piano part. I had this idea that it should sound like that so I tuned it like a guitar. I don’t know how to play banjo.

According to Slash, “Breakdown” was one of the most complicated songs to record on the album; the banjo, drum, and piano parts were hard to synchronize and drummer Matt Sorum “lost it” a couple of times trying to get the drums just right.

‘Breakdown’ can be interpreted as a song reflecting on betrayal and the fact that there is always light at the end of the tunnel. The song features Rose speaking a monologue taken from the movie Vanishing Point (1971), spoken by DJ Super Soul (Cleavon Little) while the police chase the protagonist’s Dodge Challenger.

So far, the song has only been performed twice in 1991:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LB1h_k3RCJw

songs.full_title: Catcher in the Rye by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Catcher in the Rye

description.plain:
J.D. Salinger’s The Catcher In The Rye might be hailed as a classic, but Axl here is talking about how it attracts misguided fans such as John Lennon assassin Mark David Chapman:

For me, the song is inspired by what’s referred to sometimes as Holden Caulfield Syndrome. I feel there’s a possibility that how the writing is structured with the thinking of the main character could somehow re-program, for lack of a better word, some who may be a bit more vulnerable, with a skewed way of thinking. (…) An indictment of the author for writing what I feel is utter garbage and I agree wholeheartedly that it should be discontinued as required reading in schools. That’s my take, I could be completely wrong. I do realize that the song and title could have the next poor soul reading the book and feeling inspired to make an unfortunate statement. So there’s the catch, I guess.

This piano ballad originally featured Queen guitarist Brian May, who teamed up with the band in 1999 for a collaboration. However nine years later, just prior to the release of Chinese Democracy, he was disappointed to learn that his contribution has been removed from the final version of the song. May commented: “It is a shame. I was proud of it.”

songs.full_title: Locomotive (Complicity) by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Locomotive (Complicity)

description.plain:
The song “Locomotive” was written in a house Slash and Izzy Stradlin rented in the Hollywood Hills following the Appetite for Destruction tours. It is often praised by fans because of its quality lyrical content and intricate music, particularly the outro. Slash and Izzy’s guitars meld with Duff’s bass line to mimic a chugging train.

“Locomotive” has only been played live a handful of times due it being one of the longest Guns N' Roses songs and being very vocally demanding (much like Coma, which has only recently been introduced as a regular on setlists).

Guns N' Roses planned to play this song with Jeff Beck in their televised Paris 1992 concert, but Beck suffered a ruptured ear drum in rehearsals and could not perform. However, a video of the soundcheck surfaced:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WicXPCq_2ok

songs.full_title: Yesterdays by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Yesterdays

description.plain:
“Yesterdays” was the third single to be released from the 1991 Guns N’ Roses album, Use Your Illusion II. Although the power ballad never achieved the same levels of success in the U.S. as previous Guns N’ Roses singles, it charted in the top ten across much of Europe, peaking at No. 8 in the UK singles charts.

Opening with a steady kick drum beat, the piano-trimmed song is both wistful and reflective. An air of melancholy lingers about the song, in which Axl Rose ultimately divulges the impermanence of everything. Right until the final whispered “yesterday”, Rose’s lyrics deconstruct the struggle of achieving personal growth while constantly reliving the past.

These themes are echoed further in the official music video directed by Andy Morahan. Filmed in black and white, the video combines scenes of the band performing in an empty warehouse with photographs taken during the Use Your Illusion Tour, including those of former bandmates Izzy Stradlin and Steven Adler.

songs.full_title: Street of Dreams by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Street of Dreams

description.plain:
“Street of Dreams” is a song by Guns N' Roses featured on their 2008 album Chinese Democracy. The song is the third promotional song sent to radio stations but was not released as a commercial single eligible for international Singles charts. From 2001 to 2008, the song was called “The Blues,” but was changed to “Street of Dreams” for the album’s release.

The song was originally written by Axl Rose, bassist Tommy Stinson, and keyboardist Dizzy Reed contributed some of the guitar, bass and piano melodies.

“Street of Dreams” has been a staple at Guns N' Roses concerts since 2001, being played at almost every show on the various Chinese Democracy Tours.

The song underwent structural changes during recording, most notably the drum changing from the 2007 leaked demo to the final release.

songs.full_title: Anything Goes by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Anything Goes

description.plain:
“Anything Goes” is one of the oldest Guns N' Roses songs, dating back to 1981. Originally titled “My Way, Your Way,” an early version was written by Axl Rose and guitarist Izzy Stradlin for their former band Hollywood Rose and included in the compilation album, The Roots of Guns N' Roses.



Speaking to Guitar Edge Magazine in 2007, Slash said:

Anything Goes' is one of the oldest songs on record. If you look at the credits, there are a lot of writers listed for this one because that song was around before Axl and I first hooked up. By the time Guns N' Roses got to it, we’d changed the chorus and the verses around, and Axl rewrote the lyrics. When I recorded the solo on it, I bounced back and forth between the talk box and the electric guitar. If you listen to it, the talk box dips in EQ when it switches over. I didn’t know any better because I didn’t have one to use live. I remember when we were mixing it, Izzy asked, “Did you mean to do that?” I was like, “Just shut up.”

songs.full_title: So Fine by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: So Fine

description.plain:
A love song written and mainly sung by bassist Duff McKagan as an homage to Johnny Thunders.

I actually got to jam with him one time back in ’80, maybe ’81, and I played drums when The Heartbreakers were coming through town. It wasn’t, you know, he was a full-blown junkie at the time, so it wasn’t like he was a real personable guy, but he was my hero. Johnny Thunders’ guitar playing and Steve Jones from the Pistols, those two guys really influenced how I heard music.

songs.full_title: Dead Horse by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Dead Horse

description.plain:
“Dead Horse” is the second to last track on Use Your Illusion I. Based on the expression “beating a dead horse”, the lyrics are about trying to rebuild yourself after a failed relationship. The composition starts and ends with an acoustic section, which features a guitar riff written by lead vocalist Axl Rose.

The song was never released as a single commercially, but was sent to radio stations and a music video was made for it.

songs.full_title: The Garden by Guns N' Roses (Ft. Alice Cooper)
songs.title: The Garden

description.plain:
“The Garden” is the 11th track off 1991’s “Use Your Illusion” and features guest vocals from Alice Cooper and Shannon Hoon.

The lyrics are about drug use and addiction, and the perspective shifts between the verses and chorus, contrasting the appeal with the downsides (and maybe the high with the crash as well).

“The Garden” can be considered a physical metaphor for the mental place you go to when high or hallucinating.

songs.full_title: Double Talkin' Jive by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Double Talkin’ Jive

description.plain:
Izzy Stradlin wrote the song after police found human body parts in a garbage can in the vicinity of their recording studio. It is a wonderful mixture of the energy of Appetite for Destruction and the experimentation of Use Your Illusion I and II.

Slash performs an extended Flamenco-style guitar solo at the end of the song. Live performances were stretched from its original three-minute length to more than eight minutes long.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1VbSJsRhftE

During the Use Your Illusion tour, Axl Rose introduced “Double Talkin' Jive” after “Don’t Cry” by telling the audience:

Here’s a nice pretty song. It’s dedicated to all those who can’t keep their mouths out of your fucking business. Misery likes company so if you know someone like that, call them up and tell them from me that they are DOUBLE TALKIN’ JIVE MOTHERFUCKERS!

body.plain:
Izzy Stradlin wrote the song after police found human body parts in a garbage can in the vicinity of their recording studio. It is a wonderful mixture of the energy of Appetite for Destruction and the experimentation of Use Your Illusion I and II.

Slash performs an extended Flamenco-style guitar solo at the end of the song. Live performances were stretched from its original three-minute length to more than eight minutes long.

songs.full_title: Dust N’ Bones by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Dust N’ Bones

description.plain:
This classic and yet under-appreciated track features Izzy Stradlin on lead vocals, with Axl Rose providing high harmonies in the background. It focuses on the struggles of relationships, breakups and the ever-changing feelings of women.

“Dust N’ Bones” was regularly played live during the Use Your Illusion Tour in 1991 before Stradlin’s departure from the band. After that, it was last played in 1992 when Stradlin briefly returned to the band to fill in for Gilby Clarke.

description.plain: “Don’t Damn Me” is 13th track in the album Use Your Illusion I, released in 1991. Presumably, the track was created as a response to the controversy surrounding Guns N' Roses after the release of the album GNR Lies, containing tracks with controversial content, like “One in a Million.”

songs.full_title: Sorry by Guns N' Roses (Ft. Sebastian Bach)
songs.title: Sorry

description.plain:
“Sorry” has been interpreted to be about Slash, the fans, other former members of GnR, the media, and everything in between. Vocalist/frontman Axl Rose himself said this about the matter:

With “Sorry,” like a lot of the material is drawn from a lot of different situations. The main focus on the boards with the track seems to be either Slash or “the fans” (and the collective of “the fans” is another thing that doesn’t work for me) and is much too restrictive or narrow and limits what I feel I intended. For me it’s for anyone talking nonsense at mine and the public’s expense and that many of those as well as the public don’t know who to believe. Also where possible I’d like to give people the opportunity to get what they can from the material for a while before clouding that with my inspirations. Of course that’s not always avoidable.

Written by Rose as the 10th track in the long-delayed, long-awaited 2008 album Chinese Democracy. Features former Skid Row vocalist Sebastian Bach on (nearly inaudible) background vocals.

songs.full_title: Garden of Eden by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Garden of Eden

description.plain:
‘Garden of Eden’ is the 12th track off of 1991’s “Use Your Illusion I”, written by both Slash and Axl Rose. Spanning a length of 2:41, it is currently one of the shortest Guns N' Roses songs.

The song, through its lyrics, seems to reference multiple themes or government/religious problems.

‘Garden of Eden’ has barely been played live since its release, due to it being extremely vocally demanding.

There is a music video of the song, which consists of one continuous shot which features a close-up of
 Axl Rose with the band playing in the background, whilst keyboardist Dizzy Reed and Teddy Andreadis (who played the harmonica for the band during the Use Your Illusion Tour) are seen dancing in the background.

There are two versions of the video, both made in 1992, one has paper flying through the air (this is the one mostly found on music video sites like Yahoo Music). The other version has lyrics, complete with a “follow-the-bouncing-ball”, but with no paper flying around. This is the version that is on the Guns N' Roses music video compilation “Welcome to the Videos” (in which is the 11th track).

songs.full_title: Back Off Bitch by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Back Off Bitch

description.plain: “Back Off Bitch” was written before the band’s 1987 debut album, Appetite for Destruction. The song was also played during Guns N' Roses concerts before the release of Appetite for Destruction. “Back Off Bitch” was written partially about Axl’s girlfriend, Gina Siler, who moved with him to Los Angeles in 1982, and eventually kicked him out in 1983, due to his anger issues. It was also demoed several times by the band during this period.

songs.full_title: You Ain't the First by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: You Ain’t the First

description.plain:
“You Ain’t the First” plays more like a boozy acoustic blues than the hard rock or heavy ballads the band was known for. Izzy Stradlin and Axl Rose share double vocal duties, while Slash provides the mood-setting slide guitar work. It certainly works as an interesting turn and shows much range Stradlin brought to the band.

The song was regularly performed in 1993 after Stradlin’s departure, with singer Axl Rose on acoustic guitar. It has not been played since.

songs.full_title: Pretty Tied Up (The Perils of Rock N' Roll Decadence) by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Pretty Tied Up (The Perils of Rock N’ Roll Decadence)
songs.title_with_featured: Pretty Tied Up (The Perils of Rock N' Roll Decadence)

description.plain:
Opening with the sounds of a coral sitar played by Izzy Stradlin, “Pretty Tied Up” highlights the excess of the Rock N' Roll lifestyle.

During an interview in 1992, Stradlin implied that his lyrics were inspired by an encounter with a dominatrix and her client:

My Mexican friend Tony took me to meet this woman named Margot at her house. […] We walk in and there’s this big fat naked guy with an onion in his mouth. He’s wearing women’s underwear and high heels and he’s tied up with duct tape against the wall. […] She was this dominatrix chick. […] There was this whole scene of dominatrix chicks who worked in the S&M; clubs.

In his 2007 autobiography, Slash stated that one night while writing the song, Stradlin was so high on heroin that he made a sitar out of a cymbal, a broomstick and some strings. Later, this would go on to inspire the choice of a sitar for the track’s opening melody.

songs.full_title: Right Next Door to Hell by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Right Next Door to Hell

description.plain:
Right Next Door To Hell is the first song off 1991’s Use Your Illusion I.

Axl has stated that the lyrics are about his then-neighbor Gabriella Kantor, who accused him of assaulting her with a wine bottle and a piece of chicken before throwing her apartment keys over his 12th-story balcony. Her case was dismissed by the judge for insufficient evidence. His condo was eventually given away in MTV’s “Evict Axl” contest.

songs.full_title: Shadow of Your Love by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Shadow of Your Love

description.plain:
Originally by the pre-GNR band Hollywood Rose. It featured writing credits from future Guns N' Roses rhythm guitarist Paul Tobias. It was featured on the Guns N' Roses EP with fake crowd noise overdubbed.

The song, now remastered and with the crowd noise removed, was released as a single in 2018 to promote the “Appetite for Destruction: Locked N' Loaded edition” box set.

songs.full_title: Madagascar by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Madagascar

description.plain:
The title of the song along with lyrics in chorus draw a parallel with the island of Madagascar off the coast of eastern Africa and a general feeling of being outcast from the society at large. The lyrics are largely a commentary on hope and managing seemingly hopeless situations. The sampled quotes drive the point home from various real life (or movie plot) perspectives. The main message clearly being self-reliance and the importance of not listening to the nay-sayers.

The song has a co-writing credit by Martin Luther King Jr. because that was the only way his estate would allow two of his sermons to be sampled.

songs.full_title: Nice Boys by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Nice Boys

description.plain:
This song was wrote for Rose Tattoo band. Rose Tattoo are a punk rock band, and Guns N' Roses (mainly Duff McKagan) was influenced by punk rock. And, this is a tribute to this historical band.
Recently, Angry Anderson (vocalist of Rose Tattoo) play this song in Guns N' Roses show and Slash show. In Slash show, they played this song in 2010 in Melbourne, Australia and in GN'R show, they played this song in 2013 in Brisbane, Australia. They played this song in Australia, because Rose Tattoo are Australian.
 In original lineup of Guns N' Roses, they play this song many times when they play in small nightclubs in Los Angeles. In fact, the first time they put this song in GN'R album was in Live Like a Suicide in 1985.

songs.full_title: Bad Apples by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Bad Apples

description.plain:
“Bad Apples” is commonly thought to be about Guns N Roses' temptation of taking drugs (or “Bad Apples” as they are nicknamed in the song) out of boredom and to escape their hectic lives, as well as the band themselves.

The song was written by Rose, Slash, Stradlin and McKagan and contains elements of blues and country. Stradlin’s influence is strongly evident due to the country-bluesy feel it has. ‘Bad Apples’ also includes piano riffs played by Rose and a southern accented dialogue also spoken by Rose.

“Bad Apples” has only been performed two times in 1991.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1c1-f9E23-s

songs.full_title: Shotgun Blues by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Shotgun Blues

description.plain:
“Shotgun Blues” is thought to either be about the media or Vince Neil of Motley Crue after an incident that occurred between Neil, Izzy Stradlin and Axl Rose at the 1989 VMAs.

At some point in the weeks leading up to the event, when he was on a white-water rafting trip in Idaho, Neil’s wife had gone out to the Cathouse club in Los Angeles – where she’d been allegedly assaulted by Stradlin.

Neil described the incident in Motley Crue’s autobiography The Dirt:

When Izzy walked offstage, looking like a cross between Eric Stoltz in Mask and Neil Young, I was waiting for him. ‘You f–ing hit my wife!’ I said. ‘So f–ing what?’ he spat. All my blood rushed into my fist, and I decked him. I decked him good, right in the face. He fell to the ground like a tipped cow.

Neil’s bodyguard grabbed him before he could do any further damage, but as they were making their way outside, Neil was confronted by Rose defending Stradlin.

Axl came snarling after us like an overdressed Doberman. ‘Come on, motherf—er, I’m going to f—ing kill you!’ he yelled at our backs.

Axl Rose went on to take a number of potshots at Vince Neil in the media, claiming that he threw a punch “like a powder-puff,” and even vaguely offered to fight him in Atlantic City. The Motley Crue singer responded in kind with his own challenge. Yet, for all the hype it generated, nothing more became of the tussle.

songs.full_title: Shackler's Revenge by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Shackler’s Revenge

description.plain:
The second track of Guns N' Roses‘ 2008 album Chinese Democracy. Written by vocalist Axl Rose, “Shackler’s Revenge” is a reaction to the various school shootings that have been happening in America at the time, as well as the way the media reacted to the fact that one particular shooter (the 2007 Virginia Tech one) had written a play based on the GnR song “Mr. Brownstone.”

Axl himself said this about the song in a chat he had with a forum:

 Shackler’s was inspired by the insanity of senseless school shootings and also the media trying desperately to make more out of one shooter’s preference for the Guns song Brownstone to no avail. That said, listening for my own enjoyment or if we were to make a video or performing it I lean more to the entertainment of a horror flick or something like Dexter, something with an interesting menacing character as opposed to real life.

As part of the hype behind the release of the album, this song was featured in the rhythm game Rock Band 2, which was released in September 2008 on the Xbox 360, 2 months before the album itself would be released on November of that year. That release would turn out to be the first official release of new material since 1999’s “Oh my God.” The rest of the album would later be released as playable downloadable content on April 2009.

body.plain:
The second track of Guns N' Roses‘ 2008 album Chinese Democracy. Written by vocalist Axl Rose, “Shackler’s Revenge” is a reaction to the various school shootings that have been happening in America at the time, as well as the way the media reacted to the fact that one particular shooter (the 2007 Virginia Tech one) had written a play based on the GnR song “Mr. Brownstone.”

Axl himself said this about the song in a chat he had with a forum:

 Shackler’s was inspired by the insanity of senseless school shootings and also the media trying desperately to make more out of one shooter’s preference for the Guns song Brownstone to no avail. That said, listening for my own enjoyment or if we were to make a video or performing it I lean more to the entertainment of a horror flick or something like Dexter, something with an interesting menacing character as opposed to real life.

As part of the hype behind the release of the album, this song was featured in the rhythm game Rock Band 2, which was released in September 2008 on the Xbox 360, 2 months before the album itself would be released on November of that year. That release would turn out to be the first official release of new material since 1999’s “Oh my God.” The rest of the album would later be released as playable downloadable content on April 2009.

description.plain: The final track on Chinese Democracy. Noted for symphonic elements. Rose described the blues-based guitar fills by Buckethead as some of his favorite parts of the album. Actor Nicolas Cage described it as his favorite Guns N' Roses song, calling it “amazing.”

description.plain: This is a cover of the hit song “Sympathy for the Devil” by The Rolling Stones. This song was featured in the ending credits of the 1994 drama horror film adaptation of Anne Rice’s Interview with the Vampire, as well as the closing track of Guns N' Roses‘ “Greatest Hits” album in 2004.

songs.full_title: I.R.S. by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: I.R.S.

description.plain: The song’s title is the initials of the “Internal Revenue Service.” However, the track itself appears to be referring to Rose’s former partners Erin Everly and Stephanie Seymour, both of whom filed lawsuits against him after the end of their respective relationships. This was originally leaked and played on Eddie Trunk’s radio show in New York by Mike Piazza, a few years prior to the release of Chinese Democracy. Though a cease and desist notice was given by the Guns N' Roses management, somebody taped it and put the song on the internet.

songs.full_title: Look at Your Game, Girl by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Look at Your Game, Girl

description.plain:
The song is a cover off Charles Manson’s song from the album Lie: The Love and Terror Cult. The track was kept secret, including not being on advance tapes sent out to reviewers.

The inclusion of the song caused controversy, with law-enforcement and victims-rights groups expressing outrage over its inclusion.

Axl Rose claimed:

The reason we didn’t list that song on our album is we wanted to downplay it. We don’t give any credit to Charles Manson on the album; it’s like a hidden bonus track.

Slash mentioned that the song was “done with naive and innocent black humor on our part.” Rose stated he would donate all performance royalties from the song to a nonprofit environmental organization.

songs.full_title: Down on the Farm by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Down on the Farm

description.plain:
“Down on the Farm,” originally recorded by punk band UK Subs, has only been played by Guns N Roses 11 times. It was first played at Farm Aid 1990, original drummer Steven Adler’s last concert as an official member until 2016. Additionally, it was occasionally played during the band’s Chinese Democracy Tour is 2001-2006.

songs.full_title: Move to the City by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Move to the City

description.plain:
This song was written by Guns N' Roses members, Del James and Chris Weber. Like other songs of GN'R Lies, this song was in Live Like a Suicide too.

 It’s possible this song was based on an ex-girlfriend of Axl Rose’s, Gina Siler, who moved from Lafayette to Los Angeles with Axl in December 1982.

songs.full_title: Reckless Life by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Reckless Life

description.plain: This is a historical song for Guns N' Roses. They wrote it in 1983/1984, before even forming the band. Axl Rose and Izzy Stradlin wrote this song back when the band was still called “Hollywood Rose”. In fact, this song describes their lives before the fame and money. They lived a “Reckless Life” because despite of their financial struggle they kept up a rather careless lifestyle, spending their money on cigarettes, women and drinks.

songs.full_title: Riad N' the Bedouins by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Riad N’ the Bedouins

description.plain:
Axl Rose describing the song:

Riad is the name my one time momentary brother-in-law of Erin Everly went by when I knew him. Of part Lebanese descent and a former student of Pepperdine University he claims to be an international arms dealer, billionaire with ambitions of being “King of the World”. He claims to fund several medical organizations and underground Nazi organizations around the world who says his heroes are Napoleon and Adolph Hitler. songs.full_title: Cornshucker by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Cornshucker

description.plain:
This track is essentially an ode to anal sex sang by bassist Duff McKagan, and features brutally sexual lyrics. It was recorded during sessions for GN'R Lies, but left off the album.  McKagan briefly explained how the song came about and why it was left off the record in an answer to a fan (reprinted in Dear Guitar Hero):

“I had just listened to a Mentors record. They played what you might call ‘abusive sex rock’. They were really sick dudes. GN'R were recording at Sound City and laying down every song we knew in a 48-hour period. We recorded something like 30 songs. At one point, I was out in the main tracking room playing guitar and singing a song that I was making up on the spot, and Axl goes "Dude, what the hell is that?” And I said, “It’s called Cornshucker! I Just wrote it.” He loved it. We were just fucking around and laughing. The song was too brutal to put out, even for us."

songs.full_title: Hair of the Dog by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Hair of the Dog

description.plain:
“Hair of the Dog” is the title track of Nazareth’s 1975 album Hair of the Dog. It is sometimes called “Son of a Bitch” because of the repeated lyric in the chorus. The song is about a charming and manipulative woman who can get men to acquiesce to her every need.

Guns N Roses covered this song for their 1993 punk rock covers album The Spaghetti Incident after having performed this song previously live at a Guns N Roses/Metallica/Sebastian Bach show. Gilby Clarke mentions in an interview about originally suggesting that the band should cover this song:

I did make the comment about the Nazareth tune (“Hair Of The Dog”), because I always thought Axl sounded like the singer of Nazareth. Not even knowing that the band actually played that song way before I got in the band. It was a unanimous choice to do the Nazareth tune"

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O6MTq5ElExE

songs.full_title: Buick Mackane / Big Dumb Sex by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Buick Mackane / Big Dumb Sex

description.plain:
“Buick Mackane” was originally  written and performed by T-Rex. Frontman Marc Bolan described this song as his “Zep Rex” experiment as it was inspired by Led Zeppelin – both bands have been known to use cars as sexual metaphors.

Guns N' Roses recorded this song for their 1993 covers album The Spaghetti Incident? and it features a rare backing vocal from lead guitarist, Slash.

Gilby Clarke, rhythm guitarist at the time, made it clear that he wanted to do a T. Rex cover.

“Back then I was wearing a T. Rex T-shirt, like, every single day. Matt [Sorum] used to joke, ‘Okay, we got it, we got it.’”

The last verse is taken from “Big Dumb Sex” by Soundgarden, intended as a parody of sex crazed rock bands (particularly the hair metal genre) of the 1980s. They were fed up with bands over-using euphemisms and metaphors for intercourse, and thought they would abandon that to say what disco dance bands were trying to say for a decade before.

songs.full_title: Silkworms by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Silkworms

description.plain:
Silkworms is an unreleased Guns N' Roses song. The song, an industrial hard rocker filled with synths, was written by keyboardists Dizzy Reed and Chris Pitman and performed twice by the band in the early 00’s, however, it was not included on Chinese Democracy when it was eventually released.

A  reworked, heavier version was leaked to the internet on June 11, 2018. The revamped song was played live in 2021 before being released as “ABSUЯD”, the first GNR release of new material since 2008, and the first featuring Slash and Duff McKagan since 1994.

songs.full_title: Attitude by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Attitude

description.plain:
This is a quick punk rock cover of the Misfit’s original tune from their album Static Age, with Duff McKagan on lead vocals.

The song was first performed by the band in 1991 during the Use Your Illusion Tour but was not performed again for quite some time after McKagan left. However, it has been since reintroduced to the setlist during the Not In This Lifetime… Tour.

description.plain:
“New Rose” was originally released by British punk rock group The Damned in 1976. When recently asked about the cover, the band’s co-founder, Captain Sensible, said that he had never heard it.

“The truth is, I haven’t heard it, because I don’t listen to any music made after 1980.”

songs.full_title: Oh My God by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Oh My God

description.plain:
“Oh My God” is a song by Guns N' Roses released in 1999 on the soundtrack to the film End of Days. The song was sent out to radio stations in November 1999 as a promo for the soundtrack and the band. Despite being the band’s first recorded release in almost five years, it was never issued as a stand-alone single for public retail.

The song was primarily written by Paul Tobias around 1997. Dizzy Reed wrote the hook of the chorus. Axl Rose claimed that former members Duff McKagan and Matt Sorum ‘failed to see the potential’ of the song and had no interest in recording or playing the piece.

Paul Tobias, Gary Sunshine and Dave Navarro all play on the song. Robin Finck’s part was written by Tobias and ‘extensively manipulated’ by producer Sean Beaven. Rose claimed that Finck was not involved in the writing of the final recording, although he participated in the arrangement. Finck denies he was involved with the song, despite Rose’s claim

Axl Rose later claimed that the song was an unfinished demo which was rushed to be released for inclusion with the soundtrack. Despite being played in concerts as late as 2002, it has since fallen out of the band’s setlists.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gmRLsArW6nc

songs.full_title: Scraped by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Scraped

description.plain:
The song is perhaps the most “Buckethead-y” of the songs on Chinese Democracy, with the bass and the guitar fills straight out of the playbook of the man who was raised in a coop by chickens. It’s also possibly the heaviest song on the album, and where the nu-metal/industrial rock influences shine the most.

The vocals are multi-tracked several times by Axl in the intro to create a gang chorus. Rolling Stone described the chorus as a “good old rock and roll ‘fuck you.’”

songs.full_title: Crash Diet by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Crash Diet

description.plain:
“Crash Diet” was co-written by Axl Rose, Danny Clarke (Asphalt Ballet guitarist), and frequent Guns N' Roses collaborators West Arkeen and Del James.

The demo was laid out in 1986 and was originally intended as a Guns N' Roses song. However, Axl only sang on the track as a favour to Arkeen and it never made the cut for any of their albums. When answering fan questions in 2008, Axl was asked about the story behind song and why it was never officially released. He said it was:

Somethin’ done with Wes and his friend and more about their guitars than Guns.

“Crash Diet” was later released by Asphalt Ballet on their 1993 album, Pigs (Clarke was their guitarist at the time), crediting Rose, Arkeen, and James. In 2004, the song would appear again on Wildside’s album Wasted Years.

songs.full_title: Only Women Bleed by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Only Women Bleed

description.plain:
a cover of an Alice Cooper song, used as an intro to Knockin' on Heaven’s door live. Most of the time Axl would only sing the first three lines of Verse 2, although recently the song has been used without any vocals.

Cooper toured with the group in the 90’s and was featured on the Use Your Illusion I song “The Garden”. Rose and Slash also contributed to a remake of Cooper’s song “Under my Wheels”.

songs.full_title: Ain't Goin' Down No More by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Ain’t Goin’ Down No More

description.plain:
In the early 1990s, Guns N' Roses licensed a pinball game with their music and branding. “Ain’t Goin' Down” was an outtake from the Use Your Illusion album sessions included with the game and never officially released anywhere else.



Slash had a large involvement with the game, suggesting ideas to the designer John Borg for things the band members enjoyed. Guns N' Roses were notoriously hard to get on stage and that influenced the “ADD BAND MEMBERS” right shot which would start multiball.

songs.full_title: Don't Cry (Demo) by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Don’t Cry (Demo)

description.plain: The melodic ballad, “Don’t Cry,” was one of the first compositions written by Axl Rose and Izzy Stradlin while in Los Angeles, being present in the band’s demo tape to Geffen in 1986. This is one of the three recorded versions of this song, recorded in 1986 featuring original drummer Steven Adler. It does not differ greatly from the Use Your Illusion 1 version except for a brief spoken part during the solo and Axl’s use of a lower pitched voice.

songs.full_title: Jackie Chan by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Jackie Chan

description.plain:
“Checkmate” is not the actual title for the track. In fact, aside from the band and close associates, there’s really no one who can confirm for sure what this track is as only a few seconds of it exist. In an online interview, Axl Rose referred to it as “Jackie Chan” but that’s more than likely a working title.

As the story goes, in 2006 a selection of songs were leaked to DJ Razz of IllitPress. The person responsible claimed to have worked with the band, and Razz contacted GN'R management to report him, with the hopes of scoring some VIP treatment. Meanwhile, along with more common songs, the “Checkmate” clip was included as proof that there was more out there to be had. The name was tongue-in-cheek, as there had been questions about whether the leaker really had more material, or was bluffing. Thus Razz wound up with the proof, and turned it over the management, the leaker was stopped, but Razz, unhappy that he didn’t get more of a reward, played the clip on his radio show – though in very rough quality.

songs.full_title: Black Hole Sun by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Black Hole Sun

description.plain: The band performed the song live during their 2017 tour as a tribute to their friend Chris Cornell, who hung himself on May 18, 2017. Cornell’s band Soundgarden toured with Guns N' Roses in the 90’s, and GNR covered their song Big Dumb Sex on “The Spaghetti Incident!?”. Also, Cornell worked with Duff McKagan and Slash on various projects, and Rose had stated in 1989 that he was the best current rock singer.

songs.lyrics:
My child arrived just the other day
Came to the world in the usual way
But there were planes to catch and bills to pay
He learned to walk while I was away
He was talkin' 'fore I knew it
And as he grew he said
I'm gonna be like you, Dad
You know I'm gonna be like you
And the cat's in the cradle and the silver spoon
Little boy blue and the man on the moon
When you comin' home?'
'Son, I don't know when, but we'll get together then
You know we'll have a good time then.'
My son turned ten just the other day
He said, 'Thanks for the ball, Dad. Come on, let's play
Can you teach me to throw?'
I said, 'Not today. I got a lot to do.'
He said, 'That's okay.'
And then he walked away but the smile never dimmed and he said
'You know, I'm gonna be like him, yeah
You know I'm gonna be like him.'
Well, he came from college just the other day
So much like a man, I just had to say
'Son, I'm proud of you. Can you sit for a while?'
He shook his head and he said with a smile
'What I'd really like, Dad, is to borrow the car keys
See you later. Can I have them please?'
I've long since retired, my son's moved away
I called him up just the other day
I said, 'I'd like to see you, if you don't mind.'
He said, 'I'd love to, Dad, if I could find the time
You see my new job's a hassle and the kids have the flu
But it's sure nice talkin' to you, Dad
It's been sure nice talkin' to you.'
And as I hung up the phone it occurred to me
He'd grown up just like me
My boy was just like me

songs.full_title: Sentimental Movie by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Sentimental Movie

description.plain:
This is an unreleased song from the ‘Use Your Illusion’ sessions. Recorded at R.S. Studios, Canoga Park, LA 1990.

features Duff McKagan and GNR collaborator West Arkeen on vocals. Arkeen played lead, Izzy Stradlin played rhythm and a drum machine was used for the demo. One of the only Guns N' Roses demos written and performed without the input of Axl Rose or Slash.

songs.full_title: Too Much Too Soon by Guns N' Roses
songs.title: Too Much Too Soon

description.plain: Sometime around the early Nineties, Guns N' Roses demoed a number of potential songs spanning various styles with a drum machine when they were prepping to record the Use Your Illusion albums. One of the more curious and catchy numbers to leak from the sessions is a scratchy rocker called “Too Much Too Soon.” The title is a clear reference to one of Duff McKagan’s biggest influences — Johnny Thunders, who both recorded a meandering forgettable acoustic tune with the same title and played on the New York Dolls' much-more-rocking Too Much Too Soon album — but the song’s jumpy, punky guitar riff, hip-hop handclaps and walking bass make it a fascinating GN'R anomaly.

She hit town like a rose in bloom

They moved in and made a tenement home
I said nice boys don't play rock and roll
